Award.AwardTitle: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2017: Mechanisms of phenotypic variation in Polistes paper wasps
Award.AbstractNarration:
This is an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology, under the program Research Using Biological Collections. The fellow, Sara Miller, is conducting research and receiving training that utilizes biological collections in innovative ways, and is being mentored by two sponsoring scientists at two host institutions: Michael Sheehan at Cornell University and James Highman at New York University. Character displacement is an evolutionary change in phenotype that results in decreased competition between species using the same resources or the same signals for mate choice. This process has been proposed as a key mechanism for maintaining biodiversity because it allows species to coexist that would otherwise go extinct through competition. Character displacement has been poorly examined in social insects. The United States is home to sixteen native species of paper wasps in the genus Polistes. These charismatic species exhibit striking diversity of color variation within and among species, yet occupy the same ecological niche and can have overlapping distributions. This project will provide a comprehensive overview of inter- and intraspecific color pattern diversity in these species. The fellow will test if these patterns are consistent with character displacement and will explore alternative hypotheses to explain this variation. This project will produce improved distribution maps, and detailed data on coloration and size variation for these species and will additionally develop image analysis methods that can be applied to other organisms. Data will be used to develop identification resources for researchers and citizen scientists. The fellow will mentor undergraduate students and present findings to local residents at Insectapalooza.

Thousands of paper wasp specimens are available in museum collections making this an unexploited resource ideally suited to large-scale studies of phenotypic variation. The fellow will compile specimen information and use ecological niche modeling to generate species distribution maps. Measurements of body size and high-resolution photographs will be taken for most specimens. Automated image processing will be used to measure and quantify color pattern variation in multidimensional space. To test for a pattern of character displacement, trait means and distributions will be compared between habitats with different species compositions. Color patterns will be compared with environmental variables and latitude to test for correlations among phenotypes and the abiotic environment. This project will also examine the process of character displacement by comparing trait distributions in species' body size and coloration before and after the recent colonization of the United States by the invasive wasp species Polistes dominula. Overall, this study will provide a much-needed assessment of the mechanisms maintaining diversity among social wasps.

POR.DRECONTENT:
How can closely related species live in the same habitat without one of these species outcompeting the other species? When closely related species have overlapping distributions, one proposed method by which these species avoid competition is by evolving differences in traits so that they no longer compete for the same resources. This process of phenotypic divergence, known as character displacement, can increase biological diversity and in some cases, lead to the formation of new species. This project set out to test the hypothesis that divergent natural selection is a cause of phenotypic diversity in paper wasps (genus: Polistes) and represents the first scientific study of character displacement in social insects.

There are sixteen species of Polistes wasps in North America. These species have overlapping distributions and similar ecological niches, suggesting that character displacement to avoid competition or aid in species identification may play a role in generating phenotypic diversity in this group. To answer this question, I photographed 28,000 pinned specimens of Polistes wasps from eight different Natural History collections. I first transcribed information from specimen labels to determine where each specimen was collected. Using this locality data, I created models describing the distribution of each species, and identified environmental variables correlated with the presence/absence of different species. For the majority of species, this represents the first comprehensive study of where these species occur. I developed methods to rapidly collect phenotypic data on body size and coloration for each species. Across Polistes species I discovered a pattern of community wide character displacement, also called trait overdispersion (Figure 1), in which the body sizes of different species are more equally distributed than expected by chance. This pattern is consistent with character displacement, and importantly was replicated in two regions containing completely different species. Together these findings provide the first support of character displacement as a mechanism driving phenotypic diversity in social insects. These results may lead to insights into the causes of diversification in other groups of insects.

            This project led to broader impacts in other area. I improved the curation of Polistes specimens across eight different Natural History Museums, including archiving photographs of specimens that can be used by other researchers. I demonstrated that coloration in Polistes is similar between museum specimens and newly collected specimens, color pigments are highly conserved across Polistes, and that Polistes specimens do not need to be photographed under UV light. These findings will be useful for other studies of coloration in insects. Additionally, I trained and mentored four undergraduate students in working with museum collections and coordinated outreach events promoting wasps to members of the general public.
